comments.body: i think that both html and editorState are optionals here so you don't need the `|undefined` and can go back to the `?` syntax?

both `html` and `editorState` are always passed in DraftJs, no idea why the documentation shows html as optional... I think maybe because it can be `undefined`? https://github.com/facebook/draft-js/blob/eeb71f99c2d687b2094c7f43cc5989e8942e28dd/src/component/handlers/edit/editOnPaste.js#L105

ah, I meant more along the lines of the function that you pass in here can optionally accept those params but it doesn't need to.. e.g. you can call `<RichEditor handlePastedText={(text) => 'handled'}/>`

yeah, but in that case even `text` is optional üòÑ 
If I change this to `editorState?: EditorState` from a user perspective it looks like that parameter can be `undefined`, which is incorrect.
ah yeah i was forgetting about this https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/FAQ#why-are-functions-with-fewer-parameters-assignable-to-functions-that-take-more-parameters

The `html?: string` syntax resolves the type of `html` to `string | undefined` but additionally allows you to omit the argument. If you get a valid result even if `text` is omitted/`undefined`, then all the parameters should probably be optional.

>additionally allows you to omit the argument

‚òùÔ∏è that's not true, you can omit the argument with or without the `?`, check the link @willisplummer posted

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +140,144 @@                handleBeforeInput?(chars: string, editorState: EditorState): DraftHandleValue,

                handlePastedText?(text: string, html: string|undefined, editorState: EditorState): DraftHandleValue,

                handlePastedFiles?(files: Array<Blob>): DraftHandleValue,
